title: 112_hr2786
content: The "Holocaust Survivors Assistance Act of 2011" aims to provide preference for services to older individuals who are Holocaust survivors, designate a responsible individual within the Administration on Aging, and create a grant program to enhance transportation services for this group. The Congress acknowledges the Holocaust's atrocities, with 6,000,000 Jews and millions of others murdered by Nazis. Approximately 127,000 Holocaust survivors in the US require additional support as they age. Many survivors are over 75, with a majority in their 80s and 90s, and over half of those who emigrated from the former Soviet Union live below the poverty line. Holocaust survivors, especially those living below 200 percent of the Federal poverty threshold, are a vulnerable population in the US. Institutionalized settings can have negative effects on them, triggering panic and re-traumatization due to past Holocaust experiences. Approximately two-thirds of survivors live alone, which increases the risk of institutionalization. Low-income survivors rely heavily on social service programs for personal care and meals. Holocaust survivors require services like personal care, meals, transportation, counseling, and mental health support. The term 'Holocaust survivor' is defined as an individual who lived in a country under Nazi regime between 1933 and 1945, was persecuted on various bases, and was a member of a group persecuted by the Nazis. SEC. 104. ORGANIZATION. Amends the Older Americans Act to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in certain paragraphs. Section 306 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in various subsections and clauses. Section 306 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific subsections and clauses, such as inserting them in paragraph (7)(B)(iii) and after "areas." SEC. 106 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in various paragraphs, such as (4), (16)(A), and (28)(A)(ii). SEC. 107 is also amended to include them in subsections (c)(2) and (d). SEC. 108 authorizes the program. SEC. 108 authorizes the program for older individuals who are Holocaust survivors. SEC. 109 addresses the prevention of elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation for this group. The Assistant Secretary is authorized to designate a person within the Administration on Aging for older individuals who are Holocaust survivors. It is the duty of the Assistant Secretary to improve transportation for this group. The Assistant Secretary will award grants to nonprofit organizations to improve transportation services for older individuals, with a preference for Holocaust survivors. The grants will be for a minimum of 5 years and must be used for demonstration projects or providing technical assistance to coordinate transportation services for older individuals. The demonstration project aims to create innovative transportation services for older individuals, including volunteer driver programs and economically sustainable options. It also involves preparing information on transportation resources and developing best practices for integrated transportation services. The Assistant Secretary will give preference to organizations with experience working with Holocaust survivors in awarding grants for transportation services for older individuals. The Assistant Secretary will consult with designated individuals and organizations with expertise in serving older Holocaust survivors to improve transportation assistance programs. Eligible entities must have experience working with older individuals to receive grants or contracts. An annual report on the status and needs of older Holocaust survivors will be submitted to Congress.
